author: Sean Semo
text:
Entrepreneurship isn’t about waiting for a hero, it's about constantly learning, growing, and figuring things out for yourself. 

The road to success is paved with personal effort, self-education, and the willingness to take bold actions, even when you don't know all the answers. 

The best way to learn is by doing, and every mistake is an opportunity to grow.

Stop worrying about what others think of you or your business. 

It’s easy to get distracted by opinions, but the only voice that truly matters is yours. 

Your passion, your ideas, and your vision are uniquely yours. 

You’re the only one who can lead your business forward, and the more you trust yourself, the stronger you’ll become. 

The sooner you stop seeking validation from others, the faster you’ll move toward your goals.

If you want your team to perform at their best, it starts with you. 

Treat your employees with respect, show them appreciation, and pay them what they’re worth. 

A business can’t thrive if its people are undervalued or demotivated. 

Building a strong personal brand and a loyal community is key to long-term success. 

Position yourself as an authority in your field, and always listen to your core audience.

I hope this helps

text:
The most expensive business lessons we learn come after starting the business.

This is what I’ve learned:

Having the right mindset and attitude: It’s the foundation of success.

Keeping your eyes open at all times: Opportunities and challenges are everywhere.

Never be afraid to start small: Growth begins with humble steps.

Never fearing risks but looking before you leap: Calculated risks lead to progress.

Valuing time as a precious resource: Time well spent is an investment in success.

Growing my business, Basement Brewed Fantasy Football, is the hardest thing I've ever done.

author: Sharon Ann
text:
\" The most expensive buisness lessons are not taught in books.\"

Yes, so very true. I can relate to this statement as a whole. Sharing from my own prespective when I first started my entapenuer journey 4 years ago I went to everyone for advice, a lot of the people I went too 'claimed' that if I just followed there method I'd be successful by the end of the week.

Some people told me if I just showed up and was my authentic self then I would get clients by the end of the week. Some people told me that if I did Facebook LIVES then I'd get the clients I want and long for in no time.

Yet the truth is that no matter how hard I followed others, I failed. I learned that when I did things on my own, I learned from trial and error, when I reached out to others adding my own twist to the messages, that's when I started getting people interested in collaborating with me and loads of podcast and speaking engagements that helped me to support my-self. Justin Welsh

author: Angela Blair Cadet
text:
I disagree with the first point. \"No one is going to save you\" which reeks of the hyper individualism in American capitalism. 

Similar to \"you don't owe anyone anything\" saying. Which is why the US, Australia, and UK has a loneliness epidemic (but that's a different topic). 

I'm an entrepreneur and business owner, and in my experience if you have a partner (business or married), and have other successful friends in business, you actually do have people to \"give a life line\" or \"save you\" if you need it.

No one can build a successful business or enterprise alone. All the successful businessmen and women I've met, have partners, investors, friends, and a network to tap into (or \"save\") them. Or can take a bank loan out. 

As an American living abroad and doing business in various  developing countries, no one starts a business completely alone. We all have some type of help, start up capital, or a safety net.

text: So many gems contained in this list. As a deep thinker I’m drawn to the ones that call for action rather than just studying. I need to move and do more. My one challenge would be to no. 9. How you value yourself can be particularly challenging in some communities - like women and underrepresented groups, which naturally undervalue themselves. So if you base your pricing on what you’d pay, you might be underselling. Justin Welsh how would you encourage those folks with tackling number 9?

author: Will Scott
text: Business isn't built on shortcuts—it's built on showing up, learning, and taking action.  Justin Welsh

text:
This is great, Justin. While all of these add value - here are the ones that stuck out the most to me:

1, 3, 17 and 23.

Great post to kick things off the week.

author: Susan Rensberger
text:
Based on your post, I would also say that the most useful business lessons aren't taught in books.  They're the ones you teach yourself as you work.
The same one I would disagree with is that doing is better than meditation.  They're both necessary.  In fact, I would say from my experience as a writer and a spiritual teacher and coach that your writing is a form of meditation.  Both provide a pathway for your inner wisdom to get past your problem-solving mind.
One principle I've learned is that being should come before doing.  \"Being\" is when you're in receiver mode.  You receive inspiration and guidance about what to do.
Get your guidance before you start doing.  It will make your doing easier and more effective.

author: Rob Hoffman
text: Sure, ice baths might be great for health benefits, but thinking they’ll level up your decision-making? That’s a wild take! Justin Welsh
